Mental Health Conditions (from NAMI)

Mental Health Conditions (from NAMI)
What is a mental illness?
A condition that affects a person's thinking, feeling, or mood
Can affect how one interacts with others and their functioning ability from day to day
What causes a mental health condition?
Not caused by ONE thing
Multiple linking causes...potentially:
Biochemical processes, even
Genetics
Environment
Lifestyle Influence
Traumatic life events
ie. Stressful environment can make one more susceptible
Recovery is possible
Start treatment early
Play a prominent role in own recovery
General Statistics
1 in 5 adults experience a mental health condition yearly
1 in 17 adults LIVES with a serious mental illness
Half of mental health conditions start by age 14
75% of mental health conditions develop by age 24
Normal personality or behavior during adolescence can mask or copy symptoms of a mental health condition
ADHD: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
development disorder
characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity
most commonly diagnosed in young people
Has multiple comorbidities
Approx 2/3 of kids with ADHD have another condition
Symptoms
Will struggle to control these behaviors and will show them more frequently for >6mo
Signs of inattention
  • Becoming easily distracted, and jumping from activity to activity.
  • Becoming bored with a task quickly.
  • Difficulty focusing attention or completing a single task or activity.
  • Trouble completing or turning in homework assignments.
  • Losing things such as school supplies or toys.
  • Not listening or paying attention when spoken to.
  • Daydreaming or wandering with lack of motivation.
  • Difficulty processing information quickly.
  • Struggling to follow directions.
Signs of hyperactivity
  • Fidgeting and squirming, having trouble sitting still.
  • Non-stop talking.
  • Touching or playing with everything.
  • Difficulty doing quiet tasks or activities.
Signs of impulsivity
  • Impatience.
  • Acting without regard for consequences, blurting things out.
  • Difficulty taking turns, waiting or sharing.
  • Interrupting others.
Causes
Genetics
often runs in families
some trends in specific brain areas for attention
Environmental
link between smoking and alcohol use during pregnancy
exposure to lead shown to increase likelihood
Diagnosis
Often diagnosed in childhood
Difficult to get diagnosis due to symptoms being similar to typical behavior in children
often noticed by teachers
No single test to diagnose ADHD in children
Have to rule out outside causes
Treatment
Most effective when it is individualized
Medications
stimulants
most prescribed - often first choice
affect how brain controls impulses
regulate behavior and attention
Fast-acting
  • Methylphenidate
  • (Methylin, Ritalin, Concerta)
  • Methylphenidate SR
  • (Ritalin SR)
  • Amphetamine
  • (Adderall, Adderall XR)
  • Transdermal
(Daytrana)
  • Dexmethylphenidate
  • (Focalin XR, SR Focalin)
  • Dextroamphetamine
  • (Dexedrine, Dextrostat, Spansule)
  • Lisdexamfetemine or Dimesylate
  • (Vyvanse)
CONS
reduce appetite
affect sleep
can potentially affect child's height growth if taken for multiple years
potential for ABUSE
athletically and academically
non-stimulants
Slower affect time
Affect nerves more INDIRECTLY
To increase and adjust levels of neurotransmitters (NT) in the brain
helps concentration
INC attention span
DEC impulsivity
  • Atomoxetine
  • (Strattera)
  • Guanfacine
  • Â (Intuniv)
  • Clonidine Hydrochloride
  • (Kapvay)
anti-depressants
more likely if ADHD is accompanied with depression
  • Nortriptyline
  • (Pamelor, Aventyl)
  • Desipramine
  • (Norpramin)
  • Imipramine
  • (Tofranil)
  • Bupropion
  • Â (Wellbutrin, Wellbutrin XL, Welbutrin SR)
  • Venlafazine
  • (Effexor, Effexor XR)
Side Effects
appetite
sleep problems
anxiety
irritability
Monitor Dosage and Treatment Results
Behavioral therapy
Talking with a mental health professional
Adding structure to one's life (especially as a child) can make them feel in control
Talking about appropriate/acceptable behavior
Help social skills
Sharing and interacting with peers
Learning appropriate responses to everyday situations
Self-management/assistance
Complementary Health Approaches
AKA Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM)
NOT VALIDATED by scientific research
can manage day-to-day health
  • Elimination diets
Theory that people are sensitive to sugar and artificial coloring, flavors, and preservatives
Eliminate from diet --> Improve learning and behavioral problems
  • Nutritional supplements
ie. Omega-3s to help deficiency of fatty acids
  • Interactive metronome training
Computerized metronome makes rhythmic beat that people try to match by tapping
Improvement in beat matching could indicate growth in motor planning and timing skills
  • Chiropractic medicine
Address muscle tone imbalance which can affect brain activity imbalance
  • Neurofeedback (EEG biofeedback)
Teaches how to INC activity in frontal brain areas
Because people with ADHD show low levels of arousal in this area --> impaired ability to focus
Anxiety Disorders
overwhelming and repeatedly negatively impactful
often seen with other mental health conditions to make related conditions worse
most common health concern in US
approx 40 million adults (18%) have an anxiety disorder
approx 8% of children and teenagers experience an anxiety disorder
General Symptoms
Most develop symptoms before age 21
persistent, excessive fear or worry in non-threatening situations
Emotional
  • Feelings of apprehension or dread
  • Feeling tense or jumpy
  • Restlessness or irritability
  • Anticipating the worst and being watchful for signs of danger
Physical
  • Pounding or racing heart and shortness of breath
  • Sweating, tremors and twitches
  • Headaches, fatigue and insomnia
  • Upset stomach, frequent urination or diarrhea
Causes
Genetics
some families have a higher-than-average amount of anxiety disorders among relatives
Environment
A stressful or traumatic event linked to developing an anxiety disorder
Diagnosis
physical symptoms can easily be mistakenf or other medical conditions (ie. hyperthyroidism)
Doctor do evaluation with physical exam, interview, and lab test
Use of DSM to figure out which specific anxiety disorder and any others
Treatment
each anxiety disorder has its own treatment plan
Psychotherapy
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
type of psychotherapy
explores relationships among thoughts, feelings, and behaviors
uncover unhealthy thought patterns and self-destructive behaviors
to identify negative or false beliefs, and restructuring them
Talk therapy
speak to a trained therapist in safe/confidential setting
explore and understand feelings and behaviors
gain coping skills
Exposure Response Prevention
specific for anxiety disorders like: Phobias or Social Anxiety
To develop more constructive response to fear
"expose" self to what you fear and develop effective coping tools and experience less anxiety over time
Medications
anti-anxiety meds
Benzodiazepine
short term reduction of symptoms
reduce emotional and physical symptoms
CONS
create risk of dependence
anti-depressants
useful if with co-occurring depression
Complementary Health Approaches
including stress and relaxation techniques
  • Self-management strategies
ie. provide self with specific periods of time dedicated to worrying
  • Stress and Relaxation Techniques
combine breathing exercises and focused attention to calm mind and body
could be important to treating phobias/panic disorders
  • Yoga
combo of physical postures, breathing exercises and meditation to improve anxiety management
  • Exercise
aerobic exercise can have positive effect on stress and anxiety
Types of Anxiety Disorders
Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
chronic, exaggerated worrying about everyday life
makes it difficult to concentrate/complete on everyday tasks
exhausted by worry
experience headaches, tension, or nausea
Social Anxiety Disorder
intense fear of social interaction (different from shyness
driven by irrational worry of HUMILIATION
likely to not contribute to a conversation or offer up their ideas
lead to isolation
panic attacks are a common reaction to potential/forced social interaction
Panic Disorder
panic attacks and sudden feelings of terror - randomized, repeated, and sudden
often mistaken for heart attack
Symptoms
chest pain
heart palpitations
dizziness
shortness of breath
upset stomach
many go to great lengths to not panic --> ie. social isolation
Phobias
certain places, objects, or events create powerful reactions to irrational fear
often work hard to avoid triggers
even to the extent of the fear taking over one's life
Other Anxiety Disorders
  • Agoraphobia
Fear of places and situations that might cause panic, helplessness, or embarrassment.
develops after one or more panic attacks.
  • Selective mutism
childhood anxiety disorder characterized by a child's inability to speak and communicate effectively in select social settings
  • Separation anxiety disorder
Â a child becomes excessively anxious when separated from parents.
Children with the disorder can't think about anything but the present fear of separation. They may have nightmares or regular physical complaints. They may be reluctant to go to school or other places.
  • Substance/medication-induced anxiety disorder, involving intoxication or withdrawal or medication treatment
ASD: Autism Spectrum Disorder
developmental disorder
affects ability to socialize and communicate with others
result in restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities
Spectrum = mildly impaired to severely disabled
Prevalence
1 in 68 kids and rising
Boys are 4x more likely than girls to develop autism
crosses racial, social, ethnic backgrounds equally
Symptoms
Symptoms appear at first 3 years of life
difficulty engaging in everyday human interaction
Unusual behavior parents notice first:
failing to make eye contact
not responding to own name
repetitive and unusual way of playing with toys
  • Delay in language development
not responding to own name or speaking in single words only
  • Repetitive and routine behaviors
walking in a specific pattern or insisting to eat the same thing
  • Difficulty making eye contact
  • Sensory problems
experiencing pain from certain sounds or not reacting to intense temperature shifts or pain, etc
  • Difficulty interpreting facial expressions
misreading or not noticing subtle facial cues which is helpful for understanding social communication
  • Problems with expressing emotions
ie. facial expressions, tone of voice, or gestures
  • Fixation on parts of objects
Focusing on objects vs socializing
  • Absence of pretend play
  • Difficulty interacting with peers
b/c difficult to understand that others have different views, information, feelings, or goals
  • Self-harm behavior
ie. hitting head against wall to show disapproval
  • Sleep problems
Causes
No single cause

VACCINES DO NOT CAUSE AUTISM

Genetics
If 1 child in a family has ASD, another sibling is more likely to develop it too
identical twins are highly likely to both develop autism if it is present
Scans reveal that people on the autism spectrum have certain abnormalities of the brain's structure and chemical function
Environmental
Many prenatal factors
ie. mother's health
Postnatal factors
Diagnosis
Typically diagnosis made after screening for:
Social deficits
Communication Problems
Repetitive or Restrictive Behavior
Often 2 stage process
Stage 1
general developmental screening during well-child checkups with a pediatrician
if show some developmental problems --> referred for more evaluation
Stage 2
thorough evaluation by a team of doctors and other health professionals with a wide range of specialties
may be diagnosed as having autism or another developmental disorder
Typically reliably diagnosed by age 2, but not unlikely to be diagnosed when they're older
ASD Screening Instruments
Asking parents of their child's symptoms
  • Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT)Â 
list of informative questions about a child which would indicate if they should have a further check up with a specialist
  • Screening Tool for Autism in Two-Year-Olds (STAT)Â .
set of tasks that kids perform, under supervision, to assess key social and communicative behaviors
ie. imitation, play, and directing attention
  • Social Communication Questionnaire (SCQ)Â 
series of questions for parents, to determine if their 4+ year old child needs further testing
  • Communication and Symbolic Behavior Scales (CSBS)Â 
uses parent intervies and direct observation of natural play to get information of communication development
ie. gestures, facial expressions, and play behavior
Treatment
  • Education and development
specializing classes and skills training, time with therapists/specialists
  • Smaller classes with individual time with teachers and therapists
  • Focusing on tasks that may be difficult for a few hours a day
  • Learning skills for adapting to new situations
  • Having structure and a schedule to reduce distractions
  • Behavioral treatments
Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA)
teaches kids positive behavior and discourages the negative
Floor Time
targets speech, motor, and cognitive skills through its focus on emotional development via interactive play
  • MedicationÂ for co-occurring symptoms, combined with therapy
No FDA-Approved Meds
Antipsychotics for irritability in autism
Aripipazole
Resperiodone
  • Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM)
ie. supplements and diet change
  • MelatoninÂ is a natural sleep supplement
  • Nutritional Supplements, like multivitamins, can help replenish nutrients
  • Gluten and Casein-Free DietÂ has led some families to report that taking certain foods out of their childrenâs diet has helped with their behavior
Comorbidities
Intellectual Disability
Seizures
Fragile X Syndrome
genetic disorder
most common form of inherited intellectual disability
Tuberous Sclerosis
genetic disorder
causes non-cancerous tumors to grow in brain and other vital organs
no cure, but can treat many symptoms
Rett Syndrome
developmental disorder
regression in development
mostly affects girls
often develop normally for 6-18mo then show regression with autistic-like symptoms
but then most kids improve communication skills and symptoms are no longer a concern
Other mental illnesses
Bipolar Disorder
causes highs and lows in person's mood, energy, and ability to think clearly
mania and depression
Prevalence
average age of onset is 25
but can occur in teens/childhood
affects men and women equally
2.6% of US diagnosed with bipolar disorder
83% of bipolar cases are classified as SEVERE
Symptoms
can have distinct manic and depressive states
can experience both extremes at the SAME TIME or back to back
can have extended periods (even years) without symptoms
Psychotic Symptoms
possible with severe episodes
ie. hallucinations or delusions

WRONGLY DIAGNOSED AS SCHIZOPHRENIA

Mania
experience AT LEAST 1 episode of mania or hypomania
moods can become irritable
wreckless and impulsive risks taken
unpredictable behavior
impaired judgment
unaware of negative consequences
possible to be suicidal during manic state
Depression
if ability to function is obstructed nearly every day for AT LEAST 2 weeks, can diagnose
sometimes so debilitating that cannot leave bed
Sleep problems
difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep or sleep more than usual
Negative thoughts
Minor decisions can become overwhelming
Obsessed with feelings of loss
personal failures
guilt
helplessness
suicidal thoughts potentially
Causes
Genetics
increased if sibling or parent has the disorder
NOT ABSOLUTE
Stress
stressful life event can trigger an episode
method of handling the stress can play a role
Brain Structure and Function
bipolar disorder cannot be diagnosed by brain scan
subtle differences in activation and size of certain brain areas for those with bipolar disorder
Diagnosis
physical examination, interview, and other lab tests
lab tests can rule out other illnesses, like hyperthyroidism
AT LEAST 1 episode of mania
assess pattern of symptom and level of impairment during severe episodes

Can be MISDIAGNOSED for Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD)

Treatment
Psychotherapy
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
change negative thinking and behavior associated w/ depression
to recognize the negativity
harness helpful coping strategies
Family-focused Therapy
Medications
Mood Stabilizers
Lithium
Lithobid, Eskalith
effective at stabilizing and preventing the EXTREMES of BD
for continued treatment of BD and preventing relapse
must be MONITORED CAREFULLY
SIDE EFFECTS
can cause thyroid and kidney problems
restlessness
dry mouth
digestive issues
potentially can lower risk of suicide
Anticonvulsants
also treats seizures
often recommended for BD
SIDE EFFECTS
weight gain
dizziness
drowsiness
skin rashes
blood disorders
liver problems
Valproic Acid, Carbamazepine
treat mania
treat epilepsy
effective for acute mania
potentially better for more complex/rapidly shifting BD or Cycling mania
Lamotrigine
Delay occurrences of Bipolar I Disorder
NO FDA approval for acute episodes
Anti-Psychotic Meds
Second-Generation Antipsychotics (SGA)
often paired w/ other meds, like mood stabilizers
used for manic or mixed episodes
prescribed to control acute episodes of mania or depression
dosage varies per individual
Quetiapine, Olanzepine, Fluoxetine (Symbax)
Anti-Depressants
be wary, as it can trigger mania in some
Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)
for severe mania or depression
trasmit short electrical impulses into the brain
used for symptoms that haven't responded to other treatments or special situations
Self-management Strategies
Education
Recognition of episode's early symptoms
Complementary Health Approaches
Aerobic Exercise Meditation
Faith and prayer (haha)

Consideration for Women and Kids

Women
childbearing age/considering pregnant
some meds can have risk to developing fetus or children's breast milk
being completely off meds increases the likelihood of bipolar symptoms
risky to both mother and child
Kids
must have comprehensive evaluation of physical and mental health
potentially have other mental illnesses
often receive psychotherapy and pyschosocial interventions before meds
Systematic Treatment Enhancement for Bipolar Disorder (STEP-BD)
research project to assess what treatment work for people
Types of Bipolar Disorder
Bipolar I Disorder
experienced 1+ episodes of mania
dont NEED episode of depression
manic episode must last AT LEAST 7 days
or SEVERE enough for hospitalization
Bipolar II Disorder
experience depressive episodes
shift back and forth w/ hypomania
never FULL manic episode
Cyclothymic Disorder (Cyclothymia)
chronically unstable mood state
experience hypomania and mild depression for 2 years MIN
brief periods of normal mood that lasts <8wks
Bipolar Disorder ("unspecified" or "other specified")
person doesn't meet criteria but experiences periods of clinically significant ABNORMAL mood elevation
DMDD: Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder
new mental health condition identified
could affect how bipolar disorder diagnosed in kids
describes kids who are:
intensely irritable
temper tantrums
BUT NO classic symptoms of mania
may have other mental illnesses
BPD: Borderline Personality Disorder
difficulty regulating emotion
severe, unstable mood swings, impulsivity and instability, poor self-image, and stormy relationships
struggling w/ self-regulation can lead to dangerous behaviors, such as self-harm
Prevalence
approx 1.6% to 5.9% of US adults have BPD
approx 75% w/ BPD are women
men may be equally affected, but often MISDIAGNOSED for PTSD or depression
Symptoms
wide mood swings
sense of instability and insecurity
  • Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment by friends and family.
  • Unstable personal relationships that alternate between idealization (âIâm so in love!â) and devaluation (âI hate herâ)
"splitting"
  • Distorted and unstable self-image
affects moods, values, opinions, goals, and relationships
  • Impulsive behaviors that can have dangerous outcomes
  • Self-harming behavior including suicidal threats or attempts.
  • Periods of intense depressed mood, irritabilityÂ or anxiety lasting a few hours to a few days.
  • Chronic feelings of boredom or emptiness.
  • Inappropriate, intense or uncontrollable anger.
followed by shame and guilt
  • Dissociative feelingsâdisconnecting from your thoughts or sense of identity or âout of bodyâ type of feelings
stress-related paranoid thoughts
if severe enough, can lead to psychotic episodes
Causes
Genetics
studies involving twins suggest this illness has strong hereditary links
five times more common among people who have a first-degree relative with the disorder
Environmental Facts
experiencing traumatic life events have greater risk of developing
Brain Function
emotional regulation system can be different in people w/ BPD
portions of the brain that control emotions and decision-making/judgment may not communicate optimally with one another
Diagnosis
by mental health professional after comprehensive interviews
Treatment
Self direct own treatment, what works and what doesn't
Psychotherapy
First choice in treatment
Learn methods to cope w/ emotional dysregulation
Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT)
teach coping skills
combat counterproductive urges and regulate emotions
encourages practicing mindfulness
reduce suicidal behavior and hospitalization
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
address negative thinking and behaviors
learn coping strategies
Mentalization-based Therapy (MBT)
teaches to become conscious of internal state
to develop empathy for others' experiences
develop alternate reasons for negative interactions w/ others
Medication
Not one medication to treat, just treat symptoms
For mood swings
Anti-depressants
Mood stabilizers
For disorganized thinking
Anti-psychotics
Short term hospitalization
for extreme stress
for self-harming thoughts/behavior
Depression
Prevalence
16 millions US adults (approx 7%) have had at least ONE depressive episode
some groups affected more than others
Symptoms
Changes daily functioning, often lasting over 2 weeks
  • Changes in sleep
  • Changes in appetite
  • Lack of concentration
  • Loss of energy
  • Lack of interest in activities
  • Hopelessness or guilty thoughts
  • Changes in movement (less activity or agitation)
  • Physical aches and pains
  • Suicidal thoughts
Causes
  • Trauma
when experience trauma at an early age
can change how brain responds to fear and stress
  • Genetics
mood disorders, like depression, tend to run in the family
  • Life circumstances
financial standing, relationship changes, etc can influence
  • Brain changes
Frontal lobe of brain is less active when depressed
associated w/ changes in how the pituitary and hypothalamus responds to hormone stimulation
  • Other medical conditions
history of sleep disturbance, medical illness, chronic pain, anxiety, and ADHD are more likely to develop
medical syndromes (hypothyroidism) can mimic depressive symptoms
some meds can cause depressive symptoms
  • Drug and alcohol abuse
approx 30% people w/ substance abuse problems have depression
alcohol can worsen symptoms
Diagnosis
experience depressive episode lasting >2 weeks
Symptoms of depressive episode
  • Loss of interest or loss of pleasure in all activities
  • Change in appetite or weightÂ 
  • Sleep disturbances
  • Feeling agitated or feeling slowed down
  • Fatigue
  • Feelings of low self-worth, guilt or shortcomings
  • Difficulty concentrating or making decisions
  • Suicidal thoughts or intentions
Treatment
Need specific and individualized treatment plan
  • PsychotherapyÂ 
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
assess and change negative thinking patterns
teach coping strategies
often limited use
Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)
improve problems in personal relationships
teach to evaluate interactions w/ others and how to relate
often limited use
Psychodynamic Therapy
recognizing and understanding negative patterns and behaviors rooted in past experiences AND try to resolve
looking at person's unconscious process
Psychoeducation
teaching individuals about their illness, how to treat it and how to recognize signs of relapse
  • MedicationsÂ 
Anti-depressants
2-4 weeks to begin having an effect and up to 12 weeks to reach full effect
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
act on serotonin
most prescribed for depression
  • Fluoxetine (Prozac)
  • Sertraline (Zoloft)
  • Paroxetine (Paxil)
  • Citalopram (Celexa)
  • Escitalopram (Lexapro)
Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs)
increase serotonin and norepinephrine
second most prescribed for depression
  • Venlafazine (Effexor)
  • Desvenlafazine (Pristiq)
  • Duloxetine (Cymbalta)
Norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitors (NDRIs
increase norepinephrine and dopamine
Bupropion (Wellbutrin)
causes fewer and different side effects from other anti-depressants
could cause anxiety symptoms
Mirtazapine (Remeron)
targets specific serotonin and norepinephrine receptors
can indirectly increase the activity of multiple brain areas/connections
SIDE EFFECTS
weight gain
sedation
sleepiness
less likely to result in insomnia, sexual side effects and nausea than the SSRIs and SNRIs
Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)
seldom used today as initial treatment for depression
work similarly to SNRIs but have more side effects
may also ease chronic pain
  • Amitriptyline (Elavil)
  • Desipramine (Norpramin)
  • Doxepin (Sinequan)
  • Imipramine (Tofranil)
  • Nortriptyline (Pamelor, Avantyl)
  • Protriptyline (Vivactil)
Monoamine oxidase inhibitorsÂ (MAOIs)
less used today because newer, more effective medications with fewer side effects have been found

NEVERÂ be used in combination with SSRIs

  • Phenelzine (Nardil)
  • Isocarboxazid (Marplan)
  • Tranylcypromine Sulfate (Parnate)
  • Selegiline patch (Emsam)
Mood stabilizers
Anti-psychotics
Second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs)
treat schizophrenia, acute mania, bipolar disorder and bipolar mania and other mental illnesses
  • Aripiprazole (Abilify)
  • Quetiapine (Seroquel)
  • ExerciseÂ 
help prevent mild to moderate symptoms
  • Brain stimulation therapiesÂ 
tried if psychotherapy/meds are ineffective
  • Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)Â 
for depression w/ psychosis
transmitting electrical impulses into brain
SIDE EFFECTS
memory loss et plus
  • Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS)
for severe depression
use magnet instead of electrical current for brain activation
ineffective as maintenance treatment
  • Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS)Â has a complex history
  • Light therapy
use light box to expose person to full light spectrum
to regulate hormone melatonin
Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM)
can be useful when combined w/ psychotherapy and meds
  • Exercise
can help treat mild depression
increases endorphins and stimulates norepinephrine
can improve mood
  • Folate
AKA Folic Acid or Vit B9
Can take L-methylfolate
  • St Johnâs Wort
similar chemical property to SSRIs
best not to combine w/ SSRIs and other meds = RISKY
  • Alternative approachesÂ 
Acupuncture
Meditation
Faith (haha)
Nutrition
Experimental Treatment
Ketamine
potentially quick and short-term impact on depression and suicidal thoughts
Â anesthetic with a street value (special K) that has not been studied for long-term use
Â can make psychosis worse
IF have SUBSTANCE ABUSE disorder --> best not to use
Deep Brain Stimulation
used to treat Parkinson's
Dissociative Disorders
spectrum of disorders that affect one's memory and self-perception
involuntary escape from reality
disconnection between thoughts, identity, consciousness and memory
on trauma spectrum --> may have conditions associated w/ trauma
Prevalence
2% people experience dissociative disorders - fulfill the criteria
women diagnosed more than men
approx half US adults experience AT LEAST one depersonalization/derealization episode
Symptoms
  • Significant memory loss of specific times, people and events
  • Out-of-body experiences, such as feeling as though you are watching a movie of yourself
  • Mental health problems such as depression, anxiety and thoughts of suicide
  • A sense of detachment from your emotions, or emotional numbness
  • A lack of a sense of self-identity
Causes
often develop to deal w/ trauma, to keep the memories under control
most often form in children exposed to long-term physical, sexual or emotional abuse
Stressful situations can worsen symptoms and cause problems with functioning in everyday activities
Diagnosis
doctors perform tests to rule out physical conditions w/ similar symptoms
can be influenced by a personâs cultural background
Intercultural contact may also influence the characteristics of other identities
In settings where possession is part of cultural beliefs, the fragmented identities of a person who has DID may take the form of spirits, deities, demons or animals.
In cultures with highly restrictive social conditions, amnesia is frequently triggered by severe psychological stress such as conflict caused by oppression

voluntarily induced states of depersonalization can be a part of meditative practices prevalent in many religions and cultures, and should not be diagnosed as a disorder

DID and Dissociative Amnesia
unexplained, non-epileptic seizures, paralyses or sensory loss
Treatment
Psychotherapy
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
change negative thinking and behavior associated w/ depression
recognize negative thoughts and teach coping strategies
Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT)
teach coping skills to combat destructive urges, regulate emotions, and improve relationships
add validation
practicing mindfulness
meditation
self soothing
regulated breathing
Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR)
alleviate distress associated w/ traumatic memories
combines CBT w/ visual stimulation exercises to access traumatic memories and replace the associated negative beliefs with positive ones
Medication
Types of Dissociative Disorders
Dissociative Amnesia
difficulty remembering important information of oneself
may surround a specific event or info about identity/life history
sudden onset, varied duration
no average onset age
can experience multiple episodes throughout life
Depersonalization Disorder
ongoing feelings of detachment from feelings, actions, thoughts, and sensations
like watching a movie (DEPERSONALIZATION)
feeling like other people/things are unreal (DEREALIZATION)
can experience both or either, depersonalization or derealization
duration of symptom/episode varies
average age of onset = 16
depersonalization can start from early to mid-childhood
<20% of people w/ the disorder start to experience AFTER 20 years old
Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID)
formerly known as Multiple Personality Disorder (MPD)
alternating between multiple identities
may feel like one or more voices are trying to take control in their head
identities often have their own characteristics, separate from their host
experience gaps in memory

WOMEN more likely to be diagnosed since frequently have acute dissociative symptoms

MEN are likely to DENY symptoms and trauma history

exhibit more violent behaviors
elevated false negative diagnosis
Early Psychosis and Psychosis
disruptions to person's thoughts and perceptions
difficult to determine what is real and what isn't
seeing, hearing and believing things that arenât real
having strange, persistent thoughts, behaviors and emotions

PSYCHOSISÂ IS A SYMPTOM

related to different mental health conditions
Prevalence
approx 100k young people experience per year
approx 3 in 100 people will experience an episode at some point
Early or First Episode Psychosis (FEP)
when one first shows signs of losing contact w/ reality
must be treated ASAP for the most manageable outcome
Symptoms
Warning Signs BEFORE Psychosis
gradual, nonspecific thoughts and perceptions
hard to distinguish from typical teen/young adult behavior
  • A worrisome drop in grades or job performance
  • Trouble thinking clearly or concentrating
  • Suspiciousness or uneasiness with others
  • A decline in self-care or personal hygiene
  • Spending a lot more time alone than usual
  • Strong, inappropriate emotions or having no feelings at all
Signs of Early or First Episode Psychosis
  • Hearing, seeing, tasting or believing things that others donât
  • Persistent, unusual thoughts or beliefs that canât be set aside regardless of what others believe
  • Strong and inappropriate emotions or no emotions at all
  • Withdrawing from family or friends
  • A sudden decline in self-care
  • Trouble thinking clearly or concentrating
often point to signs of health deterioration
physical and neurological evaluation would help to determine if its a mental health condition
Hallucinations
seeing, hearing, or feeling things that aren't actually there
  • Hearing voices (auditory hallucinations)
  • Strange sensations or unexplainable feelings
  • Seeing glimpses of objects or people that are not there or distortions
Delusions
strong beliefs that are inconsistent w/ person's culture, are unlikely to be true, or seem irrational to others
  • Believing external forces are controlling thoughts, feelings and behaviors
  • Believing that trivial remarks, events or objects have personal meaning or significance
  • Thinking you have special powers, are on a special mission or even that you are God.
Causes
Genetics
Trauma
a traumatic event can trigger psychosis
type of trauma, and age of person, affects if the trauma will actually result in psychosis
Substance Use
use of LSD, weed, amphetamines, and other substances can increase risk if already vulnerable
Physical Illness or Injury
Traumatic brain injuries, brain tumors, strokes, HIV and some brain diseases such as Parkinsonâs, Alzheimerâs and dementia can sometimes cause psychosis.
Mental Health Conditions
Sometimes psychosis is a symptom of a condition like schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, bipolar disorder or depression.
Diagnosis
Â If causes such as a brain tumor, infection or epilepsy are ruled out,Â a mental illness might be the reason.
Best to be diagnosed and treated ASAP
Treatment
Early or First Episode Psychosis
early treatment is preferable/beneficial
Coordinated Specialty Care (CSC)
team of health professionals work with person to create a personalized treatment plan based on person's goals
try to involve family as much as possible
  • Case management

helping the individual develop problem-solving skills, manage medication and coordinate services

  • Family support and education

giving families information and skills to support a loved oneâs treatment and recovery

  • Psychotherapy
learning to focus on resiliency, managing the condition, promoting wellness and developing coping skills
  • Medication management
finding the best medication at the lowest possible dose
  • Supported education and employment
supporting someone to continue or return to school or work
  • Peer support
  • connecting the person with others who have been through similar experiences
CSC Programs
Â Early Assessment and Support Alliance (EASA)Â 
Strong 365 (a project of the One Mind Institute)
Psychosis
Psychotherapy
  • Cognitive behavioral therapyÂ (CBT)
  • teaches people to observe and change ineffective patterns of thinking
teaches someone to critically evaluate an experience to determine whether or not the experience is real.
  • Supportive psychotherapy
  • teaches a person to cope with developing and living with psychosis
  • attempts to reinforce a personâs healthy ways of thinking and reduce internal conflict.
  • Cognitive enhancement therapyÂ (CET)
  • builds brain capacity through the use of computer exercises and group work
  • Increasing cognitive functions, such as the ability to organize thoughts, is the ultimate goal.
  • Family psychoeducation and support
  • gives families skills and support to help a loved one reach recovery
  • Â NAMI Basics,Â NAMI Family-To-FamilyÂ andÂ NAMI Family Support GroupsÂ are examples of programs the help people develop skills in collaboration, problem-solving and recovery support.
  • Peer support and support
  • connects people with others who have been through similar experiences
  • Â NAMI Peer-To-PeerÂ andÂ NAMI ConnectionÂ are examples of peer-led programs that equip individuals with the tools they need to realize recovery while building supportive, caring relationships.
Medication
Eating Disorders
preoccupied by food and weight issues that you cannot focus on other life issues
1 in 20 people will be affected in their life
often associated w/ women, but can affect men
Symptoms
group of related conditions that can cause serious emotional and physical problems
Anorexia Nervosa
Â deny themselves food to the point of self-starvation as they obsesses about weight loss
practice binge eating and purging behaviors or exercise to the point of exhaustion in attempt to limit, eliminate or âburnâ calories.
develop food rituals or eliminate food categories from diet completely
Emotional
irritability
social withdrawal
lack of mood or emotion
unable to understand seriousness of situation
fear of eating in public
obsession w/ food or exercise
Physical
low food intake and inadequate nutrition --> physically thin
body forced to slow down to conserve energy
irregularities occur, loss of menstruation
constipation
abdominal pain
irregular heart rhythms
low blood pressure
dehydration
trouble sleeping
Some people with anorexia might also use binge eating and purge behaviors, while others only restrict eating.
Bulimia Nervosa
feel out of control when binging on very large amounts of food during short periods of time
try to rid themselves of the extra calories using forced vomiting, abusing laxatives or excessive exercise
repeating cycle that controls many aspects of the personâs life and has a very negative effect both emotionally and physically
often of normal weight or even slightly overweight
Emotional
low self-esteem linked to body image
feelings of being out of control
feeling guilty or shameful about eating
withdrawal from loved ones
Physical
binging and purging can cause harm to the eating and digestive parts of the body
teeth damaged by frequent purging
acid reflux is common
excessive purging can cause dehydration
affect electrolytes
cardiac arrhythmias
heart failure
potentially death
Binge Eating Disorder (BED)
loses control of eating
eat large amount of food in a short period of time
potentially eat large amounts even when uncomfortably full or not hungry
leads to feeling _____ about behavior
embarrassed
disgusted
depressed
guilty
does not attempt to binge or excessively exercise after eating
normal weight, overweight, or obese
Causes
eating disorders are caused by people attempting to cope with overwhelming feelings and painful emotions by controlling food
Genetics
people w/ first degree relatives w/ an eating disorder are likely to develop
brain chemical, serotonin, is involved also points a contributing genetic and biological factors
Environment
cultural presence stressing "thinness" as beautiful for women or "muscular development" in men as desirable
undue pressure for unrealistic body standards
perpetuated by media, creates a strong desire to be thin
"thinness" is tied, by the media, to success, popularity, beauty, and happiness
Peer Pressure
powerful force in young people
pressure in forms of _____ due to size/weight
teasing
bullying
ridicule
history of physical or sexual abuse can contribute to some eating disorder development
Emotional Health
perfectionism
impulsive behavior
difficult relationships
lowering self-esteem
Risk Factors
Age
Eating disorders are much more common during teens and early 20s.
Gender
Â Statistically, teenage girls and young women are more likely to have eating disorders
girls/women are more likely to be noticed/treated for one
Teenage boys and men are less likely seek help
1 out of 10Â people diagnosed with eating disorders are male
Family History
Having a parent or sibling with an eating disorder increases the risk.
Dieting
Dieting taken too far can become an eating disorder
Changes
Times of change may be a stressor towards developing an eating disorder
Vocations and Activities
Â Eating disorders are especially common among gymnasts, runners, wrestlers and dancers
Diagnosis
early diagnosis is important to recovery
physical exam, interview, and lab tests
symptoms must meet DSM criteria for a diagnosis
those w/ an eating disorder are likely to have symptoms of another mental health condition
Treatment
Psychotherapy
Talk Therapy
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
helps understand relationship between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors
effective for treatment of bulimia
Medication
To treat co-occurring illnesses
Anti-depressants
Anti-anxiety
Nutritional Counseling and Weight Restoration Monitoring
help patient return to normal weight
help change old habits and beliefs about food, dieting and exercise with healthy nutrition and eating information and planning
OCD: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
repetitive, unwanted, intrusive thoughts (obsessions)
irrational, excessive urges to do certain actions (compulsions)
Prevalence
symptoms seem to appear around teenage years to young adulthood
males often develop them at a younger age than females
>2% of the U.S. population (approx 1 of 40 people) will be diagnosed with OCD during their lives
Symptoms
Diagnosis
Causes
Treatment
